sub_topic: Calculating the magnetic moment of inorganic compounds.
message_1: Calculate the magnetic moment of a transition metal complex, [Fe(CN)6]3-, with six cyanide ligands in an octahedral arrangement using crystal field theory. The complex is in a high-spin state and has three unpaired electrons.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic moment of a transition metal complex, we can use the formula:

μ = √(n(n+2)) * μB

where μ is the magnetic moment, n is the number of unpaired electrons, and μB is the Bohr magneton (9.274 x 10^-24 J/T).

In the case of [Fe(CN)6]3-, the complex is in a high-spin state and has three unpaired electrons (n = 3). Now, we can plug this value into the formula:

μ = √(3(3+2)) * μB
μ = √(3(5)) * μB
μ = √15 * μB

Now, we can multiply by the Bohr magneton:

μ = √15 * (9.274 x 10^-24 J/T)
μ ≈ 3.87 * (9.274 x 10^-24 J/T)
μ ≈ 3.59 x 10^-23 J/T

So, the magnetic moment of the [Fe(CN)6]3- complex in a high-spin state with three unpaired electrons is approximately 3.59 x 10^-23 J/T.
